messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: 3DP3: 3D Scene Perception via Probabilistic Programming

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present 3DP3, a framework for inverse graphics that uses inference in a structured generative model of objects, scenes, and images. 3DP3 uses (i) voxel models to represent the 3D shape of objects, (ii) hierarchical scene graphs to decompose scenes into objects and the contacts between them, and (iii) depth image likelihoods based on real-time graphics. Given an observed RGB-D image, 3DP3’s inference algorithm infers the underlying latent 3D scene, including the object poses and a parsimonious joint parametrization of these poses, using fast bottom-up pose proposals, novel involutive MCMC updates of the scene graph structure, and, optionally, neural object detectors and pose estimators. We show that 3DP3 enables scene understanding that is aware of 3D shape, occlusion, and contact structure. Our results demonstrate that 3DP3 is more accurate at 6DoF object pose estimation from real images than deep learning baselines and shows better generalization to challenging scenes with novel viewpoints, contact, and partial observability.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Bundle Adjustment in the Large",
        "The pseudo-marginal approach for efficient Monte Carlo computations",
        "3D Scene Graph: A Structure for Unified Semantics, 3D Space, and Camera",
        "Hopf Fibration",
        "Semantic structure from motion",
        "Method for registration of 3D shapes",
        "Benchmarking in Manipulation Research: Using the Yale-CMU-Berkeley Object and Model Set",
        "A Theorem on Trees, volume 13 of Cambridge Library Collection - Mathematics, page 26–28",
        "GRIP: Generative Robust Inference and Perception for Semantic Robot Manipulation in Adversarial Environments",
        "Holistic++ Scene Understanding: Single-view 3D Holistic Scene Parsing and Human Pose Estimation with Human-Object Interaction and Physical Commonsense",
        "Hierarchical Geometric Models for Visible Surface Algorithms",
        "Automating Involutive MCMC using Probabilistic and Differentiable Programming",
        "Gen: A General-Purpose Probabilistic Programming System with Programmable Inference",
        "Generative Hierarchical Models for Parts, Objects, and Scenes",
        "Generative Scene Graph Networks",
        "PoseRBPF: A Rao-Blackwellized Particle Filter for 6-D Object Pose Tracking",
        "Efficient nonparametric belief propagation for pose estimation and manipulation of articulated objects",
        "Learning to Exploit Stability for 3D Scene Parsing",
        "Attend, Infer, Repeat: Fast Scene Understanding with Generative Models",
        "The Quaternions and the Spaces S3, SU(2), SO(3), and RP3, pages 248–266",
        "A generative vision model that trains with high data efficiency and breaks text-based captchas",
        "Monte Carlo Pose Estimation with Quaternion Kernels and the Bingham Distribution",
        "BOP: Benchmark for 6D object pose estimation",
        "Holistic 3D scene parsing and reconstruction from a single RGB image",
        "Introduction: A Bayesian Formulation of Visual Perception",
        "Object Perception as Bayesian Inference",
        "3D-RelNet: Joint object and relational network for 3D prediction",
        "Picture: A Probabilistic Programming Language for Scene Perception",
        "Introduction to Smooth Manifolds",
        "Hierarchical Bayesian Inference in the Visual Cortex",
        "Approximate Bayesian Image Interpretation using Generative Probabilistic Graphics Programs",
        "Probabilistic Programming with Programmable Inference",
        "NeRF: Representing Scenes as Neural Radiance Fields for View Synthesis",
        "Overcoming Occlusion with Inverse Graphics",
        "Vision-as-Inverse-Graphics: Obtaining a Rich 3D Explanation of a Scene from a Single Image",
        "3D Dynamic Scene Graphs: Actionable Spatial Perception with Places, Objects, and Humans",
        "Efficient RANSAC for point-cloud shape detection",
        "Structure-from-Motion Revisited",
        "Robust 6D Object Pose Estimation by Learning RGB-D Features",
        "Deep Object Pose Estimation for Semantic Robotic Grasping of Household Objects",
        "Image segmentation by data-driven Markov chain Monte Carlo",
        "DenseFusion: 6D Object Pose Estimation by Iterative Dense Fusion",
        "PoseCNN: A Convolutional Neural Network for 6D Object Pose Estimation in Cluttered Scenes",
        "Generating Uniform Incremental Grids on SO(3) Using the Hopf Fibration",
        "Vision as Bayesian Inference: Analysis by Synthesis?",
        "Region competition: Unifying snakes, region growing, and bayes/mdl for multiband image segmentation",
        "Structured differentiable models of 3D scenes via generative scene graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in 3DP3: 3D Scene Perception via Probabilistic Programming, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
